docs.lead_paragraph: Creative entrepreneurs and some doctors are seizing on a change in Medicare rules to establish part-time rehabilitation clinics in doctors' offices, an arrangement that critics say comes dangerously close to violating laws on fraud, abuse and kickbacks. Two years ago, trying to save money for Medicare, Congress changed the rules governing physical therapy and similar services provided to people with a wide range of illnesses and injuries. The revision limited the amount that Medicare would pay for each patient's treatment and established a fee schedule that took effect this year.

headline.main: With Assorted Therapists Setting Up Shop In Doctors' Offices, Questions for Medicare

docs.abstract: Creative entrepreneurs and some doctors are establishing part-time rehabilitation clinics in doctors' offices, taking advantage of changes in Medicare rules enacted by Congress in 1997 for physical therapy and similar services provided to people with wide range of illnesses and injuries; rule have enabled health care businesses to make more money by increasing numbers of patients being treated in doctors' offices, even though fees per patient are not as high as before; arrangements show why it is difficult to control Medicare costs; critics say arranagements come close to violating laws on fraud, abuse and kickbacks (M)
